Yes, it is possible that the majority may not always agree with the decisions of the judiciary or the reporting of the press, especially if those decisions or reports challenge the views or interests of the majority.

However, this is precisely why it is essential for the judiciary and the press to remain independent and impartial. By doing so, they help to ensure that the rights of minority groups and individual freedoms are protected, even when those rights may be at odds with the views or interests of the majority.

In a healthy democracy, the majority should understand and accept that the role of the judiciary and the press is to ensure that the law is applied fairly and that all individuals and groups are treated equally under the law, regardless of their political views or affiliations. While the majority may not always agree with the decisions or reporting of these institutions, they should respect their role in ensuring the rule of law and the protection of individual rights.

It is also important for democratic societies to foster a culture of tolerance and respect for diversity, where citizens are able to engage in constructive dialogue and debate even when they have different opinions or views. This can help to reduce tensions and foster a more inclusive and equitable democratic system.
